title: Reshape SKGLView when Window.BackingScaleFactor changes (#1853)
body:
**Description of Change**

Reshape SKGLView when Window.BackingScaleFactor changes, ensuring that the output is displayed at the proper scale. If it is possible to create a test for this type of visual change, I don't know how.

**Bugs Fixed**

[BUG] macOS: When display scale changes SKGLView does not adjust appropriately

https://github.com/mono/SkiaSharp/issues/1853

**API Changes**

None

**Behavioral Changes**

None

**PR Checklist**

- [ ] Has tests (if omitted, state reason in description)
- [x] Rebased on top of main at time of PR
- [x] Changes adhere to coding standard
- [ ] Updated documentation

comments.author: mattleibow
comments.body:
Is this the only way to check? Or rather, is this sufficient?

I am thinking if you have moved the window, does it always trigger a paint - even without a render loop? Is there some window based event that we should check? What happens if you change the display scale in the system preferences?

The code looks good, I am just wondering if we should be listening to some event...

comments.author: HarlanHugh
comments.body:
Yes, moving the window between two displays of different scales triggers a paint even without a render loop. A paint is also triggered when then the display scale is changed via System Preferences.

There is an event that is fired when display scale is changed via System Preferences (NSApplication.Notifications.ObserveDidChangeScreenParameters) but it does not fire when moving the window between displays. If there is another event that fires when moving the window, I am not aware of it.

comments.author: HarlanHugh
comments.body: I moved the code as suggested. Great change. The result is visually perfect now, eliminated a brief flash that happened before.

comments.author: HarlanHugh
comments.body: I may have just discovered a better way to do this... don't merge yet.

comments.author: HarlanHugh
comments.body: Nevermind... There is an event that fires - NSView.DidChangeBackingProperties and the fix can be implemented there however doing so results in the content being redrawn at the wrong scale momentarily. Handling it in DrawRect is much better.

comments.author: HarlanHugh
comments.body: I believe this code is ready to merge.

comments.author: mattleibow
comments.body: OMG, 7 months. Sorry! Let me re review and merge. Thanks for fixing this.

comments.author: mattleibow
comments.body:
Actually, I am looking at this and see the logic in draw rect basically cancels and triggers a redraw.

What happens with the reshape event?

Is the chance basically to not have a flash?

comments.author: HarlanHugh
comments.body:
If we don't track whether the scale has been changed and call Reshape directly, it is never called unless the view is resized.

When tracking the scale from inside of OnPaintSurface where I had it originally, there was a flash. Moving it to DrawRect and bailing out when a changed is detected prevents a flash entirely.

FWIW, we have already been using this in production with thousands of users for the last 6 months.
